pages.title: Skew lattice
pages.text:
In [[abstract algebra]], a '''skew lattice''' is an [[algebraic structure]] that is a non-commutative generalization of a [[lattice (order)|lattice]]. While the term ''skew lattice'' can be used to refer to any non-commutative generalization of a lattice, since 1989 it has been used primarily as follows.

==Definition==
A '''skew lattice''' is a [[Set (mathematics)|set]] ''S'' equipped with two [[associative]], [[idempotent]]  [[binary operation]]s <math>\wedge</math> and <math>\vee</math>, called ''meet'' and ''join'', that validate the following dual pair of absorption laws

<center><math>x\wedge (x\vee y) = x = (y\vee x)\wedge x </math>,</center>

<center><math> x\vee (x\wedge y) = x = (y\wedge x)\vee x </math>.</center>

Given that <math>\vee </math> and <math>\wedge </math> are associative and idempotent, these identities are equivalent to validating the following dual pair of statements:

<center><math>x\vee y= x</math> if <math>x\wedge y=y</math>,</center>

<center><math>x\wedge y=x</math> if <math>x\vee y=y</math>.<ref name="Leech, J 1989">Leech, J, Skew lattices in rings, Algebra Universalis, 26(1989), 48-72.</ref> </center>

==Historical background==
For over 60 years, noncommutative variations of lattices have been studied with differing motivations.  For some the motivation has been an interest in the conceptual boundaries of [[lattice theory]]; for others it was a search for noncommutative forms of [[Mathematical logic|logic]] and [[Boolean algebra (logic)|Boolean algebra]]; and for others it has been the behavior of [[idempotent]]s in [[Ring (mathematics)|rings]].  A ''noncommutative lattice'', generally speaking, is an [[Algebraic structure|algebra]] <math>(S; \wedge, \vee)</math> where <math>\wedge </math> and <math>\vee </math> are [[Associative operation|associative]], [[idempotent]] [[Binary operation|binary]] [[Operation (mathematics)|operations]] connected by [[Absorption Identities|absorption identities]] guaranteeing that <math>\wedge </math> in some way dualizes <math>\vee </math>. The precise identities chosen depends upon the underlying motivation, with differing choices producing distinct [[Variety (universal algebra)|varieties of algebras]].  

[[Pascual Jordan]], motivated by questions in [[quantum logic]], initiated a study of ''noncommutative lattices'' in his 1949 paper, ''Über Nichtkommutative Verbände'',<ref name="JO49">Jordan, P. Uber Nichtkommutative Verbände, Arch. Math. 2 (1949), 56–59.</ref> choosing the absorption identities

<center><math>x\wedge (y\vee x) = x = (x\wedge y)\vee x.</math></center>

He referred to those algebras satisfying them as ''Schrägverbände''.  By varying or augmenting these identities, Jordan and others obtained a number of varieties of noncommutative lattices.
Beginning with Jonathan Leech's 1989 paper, ''Skew lattices in rings'',<ref name="LE89">Leech, J, Skew lattices in rings, Algebra Universalis, 26(1989), 48-72</ref> skew lattices as defined above have been the primary objects of study.  This was aided by previous results about [[Band (mathematics)|band]]s. This was especially the case for many of the basic properties.

==Basic properties==
'''Natural partial order and natural quasiorder'''

In a skew lattice <math>S</math>, the natural [[partial order]] is defined by <math>y\leq x</math> if <math>x \wedge y = y = y \wedge x</math>, or dually, <math>x \vee y = x = y \vee x</math>. The natural [[preorder]] on <math>S</math> is given by <math>y \preceq x</math> if <math>y \wedge x\wedge y = y</math> or dually <math>x \vee y \vee x = x</math>. While <math>\leq</math> and <math>\preceq</math> agree on lattices, <math>\leq</math> properly refines <math>\preceq</math> in the noncommutative case. The induced natural [[Equivalence relation|equivalence]] <math>D</math> is defined by <math>xDy</math> if <math>x \preceq y \preceq x</math>, that is, <math>x \wedge y \wedge x = x </math>
and <math>y \wedge x \wedge y = y</math> or dually, <math>x \vee y \vee x = x</math> and <math>y \vee x \vee y = y</math>. The blocks of the partition <math>S/D</math> are
lattice ordered by <math>A > B</math> if <math>a \in A</math> and <math>b \in B</math> exist such that <math>a > b</math>. This permits us to draw [[Hasse diagram]]s of skew lattices such as the following pair:

<center>[[File:Skew diag.png]]</center>

E.g., in the diagram on the left above, that <math>a</math> and <math>b</math> are <math>D</math> related is expressed by the dashed
segment. The slanted lines reveal the natural partial order between elements of the distinct <math>D</math>-classes. The elements <math>1</math>, <math>c</math> and <math>0</math> form the singleton <math>D</math>-classes.

'''Rectangular Skew Lattices'''

Skew lattices consisting of a single <math>D</math>-class are called '''rectangular'''. They are characterized by the equivalent identities: <math>x \wedge y \wedge x = x</math>, <math>y \vee x \vee y = y</math> and <math>x \vee y = y \wedge x</math>. Rectangular skew lattices are isomorphic to skew lattices having the following construction (and conversely): given nonempty
sets <math>L</math> and <math>R</math>, on <math>L \times R</math> define <math>(x, y) \vee (z , w ) = (z , y)</math> and <math>(x, y) \wedge (z , w ) = (x, w )</math>. The <math>D</math>-class partition of a skew lattice <math>S</math>, as indicated in the above diagrams, is the unique partition of <math>S</math> into its maximal rectangular subalgebras, Moreover, <math>D</math> is a congruence with the induced quotient algebra <math>S/ D</math> being the maximal lattice image of <math>S</math> , thus making every skew lattice <math>S</math> a lattice of rectangular subalgebras. This is the Clifford–McLean Theorem for skew lattices, first given for bands separately by [[Alfred H. Clifford|Clifford]] and McLean. It is also known as ''the First Decomposition Theorem for skew lattices''.

'''Right (left) handed skew lattices and the Kimura factorization'''

A skew lattice is right-handed if it satisfies the identity <math>x\wedge y \wedge x = y \wedge x</math> or dually, <math>x \vee y \vee x = x \vee y</math>.
These identities essentially assert that <math>x \wedge y = y</math> and <math>x \vee y = x</math> in each <math>D</math>-class. Every skew lattice <math>S</math> has a unique maximal right-handed image <math>S/ L</math> where the congruence <math>L</math> is defined by <math>xLy</math> if both <math>x \wedge y = x</math> and <math>y \wedge x = y </math> (or dually, <math>x \vee y = y</math> and <math>y \vee x = x</math>). Likewise a skew lattice is left-handed if <math>x \wedge y = x</math> and <math>x \vee y = y</math> in each <math>D</math>-class. Again the maximal left-handed image of a skew lattice <math>S</math> is the image <math>S/ R</math> where the congruence <math>R</math> is defined in dual fashion to <math>L</math>. Many examples of skew lattices are either right or left-handed. In the lattice of congruences, <math>R \vee L = D</math> and <math>R \cap L</math> is the identity congruence <math>\Delta </math>. The induced epimorphism <math>S\rightarrow S/D</math> factors through both induced epimorphisms <math>S \rightarrow S/L</math> and <math>S \rightarrow S/R</math>. Setting <math>T = S/D</math>, the homomorphism <math>k : S \rightarrow S/L \times S/R</math> defined by <math>k(x) = (L_x, R_x)</math>, induces an isomorphism <math>k* : S\sim S/ L \times _T S/R</math>. This is the Kimura factorization of <math>S</math> into a fibred product of its maximal right and left-handed images.

<center>[[File:Skew pullback.png]]</center>

Like the Clifford–McLean Theorem, Kimura factorization (or the ''Second Decomposition Theorem for skew lattices'') was first given for regular bands (that satisfy the middle absorption
identity, <math>xyxzx = xyzx</math> ). Indeed, both <math>\wedge </math> and <math>\vee </math> are regular band operations. The above symbols <math>D</math>, <math>R</math> and <math>L</math> come, of course, from basic semigroup theory.<ref name="LE89"/><ref name="LE96">Leech, J, Recent developments in the theory of skew lattices, [[Semigroup Forum]], 52(1996), 7-24.</ref><ref name="LE05">Leech, J, Magic squares, finite planes and simple quasilattices, Ars Combinatoria 77(2005), 75-96.</ref><ref name="LE93">Leech, J, The geometry of skew lattices, [[Semigroup Forum]], 52(1993), 7-24.</ref><ref name="LE92">Leech, J, Normal skew lattices, [[Semigroup Forum]], 44(1992), 1-8.</ref><ref name="KA07">Cvetko-Vah, K, Internal decompositions of skew lattices, Communications in Algebra, 35 (2007), 243-247</ref><ref name="CV06B">Cvetko-Vah, K, A new proof of Spinks’ Theorem, [[Semigroup Forum]] 73 (2006), 267-272.</ref><ref name="LA02">Laslo, G and Leech, J, Green’s relations on noncommutative lattices, Acta Sci. Math. (Szeged), 68 (2002), 501-533.</ref>

==Subvarieties of skew lattices==
Skew lattices form a variety. Rectangular skew lattices, left-handed and right-handed skew lattices all form subvarieties that are central to the basic structure theory of skew lattices. Here are several
more.

'''Symmetric Skew Lattices'''

A skew lattice S is symmetric if for any <math>x, y \in S</math> , <math>x \wedge y = y \wedge x</math> if <math>x \vee y = y \vee x</math>. Occurrences of commutation are thus unambiguous for such skew lattices, with subsets of pairwise commuting elements generating commutative subalgebras, i.e., sublattices. (This is not true for skew lattices in general.) Equational bases for this subvariety, first given by Spinks<ref name="SP98">Spinks, M, Automated deduction in non-commutative lattice theory, Tech. Report 3/98, Monash U,  GSCIT, 1998</ref> are:
<math>x \vee y \vee (x \wedge y) = (y \wedge x) \vee y \vee x</math> and <math>x \wedge y \wedge (x \vee y) = (y \vee x) \wedge y \wedge x</math>.
A '''lattice section''' of a skew lattice <math>S</math> is a sublattice <math>T</math> of <math>S</math> meeting each <math>D</math>-class of <math>S</math> at a single element. <math>T</math> is thus an internal copy of the lattice <math>S/ D</math> with the composition <math>T \subset S \rightarrow S/D</math> being an isomorphism. All symmetric skew lattices for which |S/D| \leq \aleph_0, admit a lattice section.<ref name="LA02"/> Symmetric or not, having a lattice section <math>T</math> guarantees that <math>S</math> also has internal copies of <math>S/ L</math> and <math>S/ R</math> given respectively by <math>T [R] = \bigcup_{t\in T} R_t</math> and <math>T [L] = \bigcup_{t\in T}  L_t</math>, where <math>R_t</math> and <math>Lt</math> are the <math>R</math> and <math>L</math> congruence classes of <math>t</math> in <math>T</math> . Thus <math>T [ R] \subset S \rightarrow S/L</math> and <math>T [L] \subset S \rightarrow S/R</math> are isomorphisms.<ref name="KA07"/> This leads to a commuting diagram of embedding dualizing the preceding Kimura diagram.

<center>[[File:Skew lsection.png]]</center>

'''Cancellative Skew Lattices'''

A skew lattice is cancellative if <math>x \vee y = x \vee z</math> and <math>x \wedge y = x \wedge z</math> implies <math>y = z</math> and likewise <math>x \vee z = y \vee z</math> and <math>x \wedge z = y \wedge z</math> implies <math>x = y</math>. Cancellatice skew lattices are symmetric and can be shown to form a variety. Unlike lattices, they need not be distributive, and conversely.

'''Distributive Skew Lattices'''

Distributive skew lattices are determined by the identities:
<math>x \wedge (y \vee z ) \wedge x = (x \wedge y \wedge x) \vee (x \wedge z \wedge x)</math>  (D1)
<math>x \vee (y \wedge z ) \vee x = (x \vee y \vee x) \wedge (x \vee z \vee x).</math> (D'1)

Unlike lattices, (D1) and (D'1) are not equivalent in general for skew lattices, but they are for symmetric skew lattices.<ref name="CV06B"/><ref>Spinks, M, Automated deduction in non-commutative lattice theory, Tech. Report 3/98, Monash University, Gippsland School of Computing and Information Technology, June 1998</ref><ref name="SP00"/> The condition (D1) can be strengthened to <math>x \wedge (y \vee z ) \wedge w = (x \wedge y \wedge w) \vee (x \wedge z \wedge w) </math> (D2) in which case (D'1) is a consequence. A skew lattice <math>S</math> satisfies both (D2) and its dual, <math>x \vee (y \wedge z ) \vee w = (x \vee y \vee w) \wedge (x \vee z \vee w)</math>, if and only if it factors as the product of a distributive lattice and a rectangular skew lattice. In this latter case (D2) can be strengthened to <math>x \wedge (y \vee z ) = (x \wedge y) \vee (x \wedge z )</math> and <math>(y \vee z ) \wedge w = (y \wedge w) \vee (z \wedge w)</math>. (D3)
On its own, (D3) is equivalent to (D2) when symmetry is added.<ref name="LE89"/> We thus have six subvarieties of skew lattices determined respectively by (D1), (D2), (D3) and their duals.

'''Normal Skew Lattices'''

As seen above, <math>\wedge </math> and <math>\vee </math> satisfy the identity <math>xyxzx = xyzx</math>. Bands satisfying the stronger identity, <math>xyzx = xzyx</math>, are called normal. A skew lattice is normal skew if it satisfies

<math>x \wedge y \wedge z \wedge x = x \wedge z \wedge y \wedge x. (N) </math>

For each element a in a normal skew lattice <math>S</math>, the set <math>a \wedge S \wedge a</math> defined by { <math>a \wedge x \wedge a | x \in S </math>} or equivalently {<math> x \in S | x\leq a </math>} is a sublattice of <math>S</math>, and conversely. (Thus normal skew lattices have also been called local lattices.) When both <math>\wedge</math> and <math>\vee</math> are normal, <math>S</math> splits isomorphically into a product <math>T \times D</math> of a lattice <math>T</math> and a rectangular skew lattice <math>D</math>, and conversely. Thus both normal skew lattices and split skew lattices form varieties. Returning to distribution, <math>(D2) = (D1) + (N)</math> so that <math>(D2)</math> characterizes the variety of distributive, normal skew lattices, and (D3) characterizes the variety of symmetric, distributive, normal skew lattices.

'''Categorical Skew Lattices'''

A skew lattice is categorical if nonempty composites of coset bijections are coset bijections. Categorical skew lattices form a variety. Skew lattices in rings and normal skew lattices are examples
of algebras on this variety.<ref name="LE96"/> Let <math>a > b > c</math> with <math>a \in A</math>, <math>b \in B</math> and <math>c \in C</math>, <math>\varphi</math> be the coset bijection from <math>A</math> to <math>B</math> taking <math>a</math> to <math>b</math>, <math>\psi</math> be the coset bijection from <math>B</math> to <math>C</math> taking <math>b</math> to <math>c</math> and finally <math>\chi</math> be the coset bijection from <math>A</math> to <math>C</math> taking <math>a</math> to <math>c</math>. A skew lattice <math>S</math> is categorical if one always has the equality <math>\psi \circ \varphi = \chi</math>, i.e. , if the
composite partial bijection <math>\psi \circ \varphi</math> if nonempty is a coset bijection from a <math>C</math> -coset of <math>A</math> to an <math>A</math>-coset
of <math>C</math> . That is <math>(A \wedge b \wedge A) \cap (C \vee b \vee C ) = (C \vee a \vee C ) \wedge b \wedge (C \vee a \vee C ) = (A \wedge c \wedge A) \vee b \vee (A \wedge c \wedge A)</math>.
All distributive skew lattices are categorical. Though symmetric skew lattices might not be. In a sense they reveal the independence between the properties of symmetry and distributivity.<ref name="LE89"/><ref name="LE96"/><ref name="LE93"/><ref name="CV06B"/><ref name="LA02"/><ref name="SP98"/><ref name="SP00">Spinks, M, On middle distributivity for skew lattices, [[Semigroup Forum]] 61 (2000), 341-345.</ref><ref name="CV10">Cvetko-Vah, Karin ; Kinyon, M. ; Leech, J. ; Spinks, M. Cancellation in skew Lattices. [[Order (journal)|Order]] 28 (2011), 9-32.</ref>

==Skew Boolean algebras==
A zero element in a skew lattice S is an element 0 of S such that for all <math>x \in S </math>, <math>0 \wedge x = 0 = x \wedge 0</math> or, dually, <math>0 \vee x = x = x \vee 0</math>. (0)

A Boolean skew lattice is a symmetric, distributive normal skew lattice with 0, <math>(S ; \vee, \wedge, 0)</math>, such that <math>a \wedge S \wedge a</math> is a Boolean lattice for each <math>a \in S </math>. Given such skew lattice S, a difference operator \ is defined by x\ y = <math>x - x \wedge y \wedge x</math> where the latter is evaluated in the Boolean lattice <math>x \wedge S \wedge x</math>.<ref name="Leech, J 1989"/> In the presence of (D3) and (0), \ is characterized by the identities:
<math>y \wedge x/y = 0 = x/y \wedge y</math> and <math>(x \wedge y \wedge x) \vee x/y = x = x/y \vee (x \wedge y \wedge x). (S B)</math>
One thus has a variety of skew Boolean algebras <math>(S ; \vee, \wedge, /, 0)</math> characterized by identities (D3), (0) and (S B). A primitive skew Boolean algebra consists of 0 and a single non-0 D-class. Thus it is the result of adjoining a 0 to a rectangular skew lattice D via (0) with <math>x/y = x</math>, if <math>y = 0</math>
and <math>0</math> otherwise. Every skew Boolean algebra is a subdirect product of primitive algebras. Skew Boolean algebras play an important role in the study of discriminator varieties and other generalizations in universal algebra of Boolean behavior.
<ref name="BI76">Bignall, R. J., Quasiprimal Varieties and Components of Universal Algebras, Dissertation, The Flinders University of South Australia, 1976.</ref>
<ref name="BI91">Bignall, R J, A non-commutative multiple-valued logic, Proc. 21st International Symposium
on Multiple-valued Logic, 1991, IEEE Computer Soc. Press, 49-54.</ref>
<ref name="BI95">Bignall, R J and J Leech, Skew Boolean algebras and discriminator varieties, Algebra Universalis, 33(1995), 387-398.</ref>
<ref name="BI96">Bignall, R J and M Spinks, Propositional skew Boolean logic, Proc. 26th International Symposium on Multiple-valued Logic, 1996, IEEE Computer Soc. Press, 43-48.</ref>
<ref name="BI03">Bignall, R J and M Spinks, Implicative BCS-algebra subreducts of skew Boolean algebras, Scientiae Mathematicae Japonicae, 58 (2003), 629-638.</ref>
<ref name="BI10">Bignall, R J and M Spinks, On binary discriminator varieties (I): Implicative BCS-algebras, International Journal of Algebra and Computation, to appear.</ref> 
<ref name="CO80">Cornish, W H, Boolean skew algebras, Acta Math. Acad. Sci. Hung., 36 (1980), 281-291.</ref>
<ref name="LE90">Leech, J, Skew Boolean algebras, Algebra Universalis, 27(1990), 497-506.</ref>
<ref name="LE08">Leech and Spinks, Skew Boolean algebras generated from generalized Boolean algebras, Algebra Universalis 58 (2008), 287-302, 307-311.</ref>
<ref name="SP02">Spinks, M, Contributions to the Theory of Pre-BCK Algebras, Monash University Dissertation, 2002.</ref> 
<ref name="SP06">Spinks, M and R Veroff, Axiomatizing the skew Boolean propositional calculus, J.Automated Reasoning, 37 (2006), 3-20.</ref>

==Skew lattices in rings==
Let <math>A</math> be a [[Ring (mathematics)|ring]]  and let <math>E(A)</math> denote the [[Set (mathematics)|set]] of all [[Idempotent]]s in <math>A</math>. For all <math>x, y \in A</math> set <math>x \wedge y = xy</math> and <math>x \vee y = x + y - xy </math>.

Clearly <math>\wedge </math> but also <math>\vee </math> is [[associative]]. If a subset <math>S \subseteq E(A)</math> is closed under <math>\wedge </math> and <math>\vee </math>, then <math>(S, \wedge, \vee)</math> is a distributive, cancellative skew lattice. To find such skew lattices in <math>E(A)</math> one looks at bands in <math>E(A)</math>, especially the ones that are maximal with respect to some constraint. In fact, every multiplicative band in <math>()</math> that is maximal with respect to being right regular (= ) is also closed under <math>\vee </math> and so forms a right-handed skew lattice. In general, every right regular band in <math>E(A)</math> generates a right-handed skew lattice in <math>E(A)</math>. Dual remarks also hold for left regular bands (bands satisfying the identity <math>xyx = xy</math>) in <math>E(A)</math>. Maximal regular bands need not to be closed under <math>\vee </math> as defined; counterexamples are easily found using multiplicative rectangular bands. These cases are closed, however, under the cubic variant of <math>\vee </math> defined by <math>x \nabla y = x + y + yx - xyx - yxy </math> since in these cases <math>x \nabla y</math> reduces to <math>yx</math> to give the dual rectangular band. By replacing the condition of regularity by normality <math>(xyz w = xz yw)</math>, every maximal normal multiplicative band <math>S</math> in <math>E(A)</math> is also closed under <math>\nabla</math> with <math>(S ; \wedge, \vee, /, 0)</math>, where <math>x/y = x - xyx</math>, forms a Boolean skew lattice. When <math>E(A)</math> itself is closed under multiplication, then it is a normal band and thus forms a Boolean skew lattice. In fact, any skew Boolean algebra can be embedded into such an algebra.<ref name="CV05A">Cvetko-Vah, K, Skew lattices in matrix rings, Algebra Universalis 53 (2005), 471-479.</ref> When A has a multiplicative identity <math>1</math>, the condition that <math>E(A)</math> is multiplicatively closed is well-known to imply that <math>E(A)</math> forms a Boolean algebra. Skew lattices in rings continue to be a good source of examples and motivation.<ref name="LE08"/><ref name="CV04">Cvetko-Vah, K, Pure skew lattices in rings, [[Semigroup Forum]] 68 (2004), 268-279.</ref><ref name="KA05B">Cvetko-Vah, K, Pure ∇-bands, [[Semigroup Forum]] 71 (2005), 93-101.</ref><ref name="KA05A">Cvetko-Vah, K, Skew lattices in rings, Dissertation, University of Ljubljana, 2005.</ref><ref name="KA08">Cvetko-Vah, K and J Leech, Associativity of the ∇-operation on bands in rings, [[Semigroup Forum]] 76 (2008), 32-50</ref>

==Primitive skew lattices==
Skew lattices consisting of exactly two D-classes are called primitive skew lattices.  Given such a skew lattice <math>S</math> with <math>D</math>-classes <math>A > B</math> in <math>S/D</math>, then for any <math>a \in A</math> and <math>b \in B</math>, the subsets

<math>A \wedge b \wedge A =</math>{<math>u \wedge b \wedge u : u \in A</math>} <math>\subseteq B</math>   and   <math>B \vee a \vee B =</math> {<math>v \vee a \vee v : v \in B</math>} <math>\subseteq A</math>

are called, respectively, ''cosets of A in B'' and ''cosets of B in A''.  These cosets partition B and A with <math>b \in A\wedge b\wedge A</math> and <math>a \in B\wedge a\wedge B</math>.  Cosets are always rectangular subalgebras in their <math>D</math>-classes.  What is more, the partial order <math>\geq </math> induces a coset bijection <math>\varphi : B \vee a \vee B \rightarrow A \wedge b \wedge A</math> defined by:

<math>\phi (x) = y</math>  iff  <math>x > y</math>, for <math>x \in B \vee a \vee B</math> and <math>y \in A \wedge b \wedge A</math>.

Collectively, coset bijections describe <math>\geq </math> between the subsets <math>A</math> and <math>B</math>.  They also determine <math>\vee </math> and <math>\wedge</math> for pairs of elements from distinct <math>D</math>-classes.  Indeed, given <math>a \in A</math> and <math>b \in B</math>, let <math>\varphi </math> be the
cost bijection between the cosets <math>B\vee a\vee B</math> in <math>A</math> and <math>A \wedge b \wedge A</math> in <math>B</math>.  Then:

<math>a\vee b = a\vee \varphi -1(b), b\vee a = \varphi -1(b)\vee a</math>  and <math> a\wedge b = \varphi(a)\wedge b , b\wedge a = b\wedge \varphi (a)</math>.

In general, given <math>a, c \in A</math> and <math>b, d \in B</math> with <math>a > b</math> and <math>c > d</math>, then <math>a, c</math> belong to a common <math>B</math>- coset in <math>A</math> and <math>b, d</math> belong to a common <math>A</math>-coset in <math>B</math> if and only if <math>a > b // c > d</math>.  Thus each coset bijection is, in some sense, a maximal collection of mutually parallel pairs <math>a > b</math>.

Every primitive skew lattice <math>S</math> factors as the fibred product of its maximal left and right- handed primitive images <math>S/R \times_2 S/L</math>.  Right-handed primitive skew lattices are constructed as follows.  Let <math>A = \cup _i A_i</math> and <math>B = \cup _j B_j</math> be partitions of disjoint nonempty sets <math>A</math> and <math>B</math>, where all <math>A_i</math> and <math>B_j</math> share a common size.  For each pair <math>i, j</math> pick a fixed bijection <math>\varphi_i,j</math> from <math>A_i</math> onto <math>B_j</math>.  On <math>A</math> and <math>B</math> separately set <math>x\wedge y = y</math> and <math>x\vee y = x</math>; but given <math>a \in A</math> and <math>b \in B</math>, set

<math>a \vee b = a, b \vee a = a', a \wedge b = b</math> and <math>b \wedge a = b' </math>

where <math>\varphi_{i,j}(a') = b</math> and <math>\varphi_{i,j}(a) = b'</math> with <math>a'</math> belonging to the cell <math>A_i</math> of <math>a</math> and <math>b'</math> belonging to the cell <math>B_j</math> of <math>b</math>.  The various <math>\varphi i,j</math> are the coset bijections.  This is illustrated in the following partial Hasse diagram where <math>|A_i| = |B_j| = 2</math> and the arrows indicate the <math>\varphi_{i,j}</math> -outputs and <math>\geq </math> from <math>A</math> and <math>B</math>.

<center>[[File:Skew primitive.png]]</center>

One constructs left-handed primitive skew lattices in dual fashion.  All right [left] handed primitive skew lattices can be constructed in this fashion.<ref name="LE89"/>

==The coset structure of skew lattices==
A nonrectangular skew lattice <math>S</math> is covered by its maximal primitive skew lattices: given comparable <math>D</math>-classes <math>A > B</math> in <math>S/D</math>, <math>A \cup B</math> forms a maximal primitive subalgebra of <math>S</math> and every <math>D</math>-class in <math>S</math> lies in such a subalgebra.  The coset structures on these primitive subalgebras combine to determine the outcomes <math>x\vee y</math> and <math>x\wedge y</math> at least when <math>x</math> and <math>y</math> are comparable under <math>\preceq </math>.  It turns out that <math>x\vee y</math> and <math>x\wedge y</math> are determined in general by cosets and their bijections, although in
a slightly less direct manner than the <math>\preceq </math>-comparable case.  In particular, given two incomparable D-classes A and B with join D-class J and meet D-class <math>M</math> in <math>S/D</math>, interesting connections arise between the two coset decompositions of J (or M) with respect to A and B.<ref name="LE96"/>

<center>[[File:Skew diamond.png]]</center>

Thus a skew lattice may be viewed as a coset atlas of rectangular skew lattices placed on the vertices of a lattice and coset bijections between them, the latter seen as partial isomorphisms
between the rectangular algebras with each coset bijection determining a corresponding pair of cosets.  This perspective gives, in essence, the Hasse diagram of the skew lattice, which is easily
drawn in cases of relatively small order.  (See the diagrams in Section 3 above.) Given a chain of D-classes <math>A > B > C</math> in <math>S/D</math>, one has three sets of coset bijections: from A to B, from B to C and from A to C.  In general, given coset bijections <math>\varphi: A \rightarrow B</math> and <math>\psi: B \rightarrow C</math>, the composition of partial bijections <math>\psi \varphi </math> could be empty.  If it is not, then a unique coset bijection <math>\chi: A \rightarrow C </math> exists such that <math>\psi \varphi \subseteq \chi </math>.  (Again, <math>\chi </math> is a bijection between a pair of cosets in <math>A</math> and <math>C</math>.)  This inclusion can be strict.  It is always an equality (given <math>\psi \varphi \neq \empty </math>) on a given skew lattice S precisely when S is categorical.  In this case, by including the identity maps on each rectangular D-class and adjoining empty bijections between properly comparable D-classes, one has a category of rectangular algebras and coset bijections between them.   The simple examples in Section 3 are categorical.

Spectral space
pages.text:
In [[mathematics]], a '''spectral space''' (sometimes called a '''coherent space''') is a [[topological space]] that is [[homeomorphic]] to the [[Spectrum of a ring|spectrum of a commutative ring]].

==Definition==

Let ''X'' be a topological space and let ''K<sup><math>\circ</math></sup>(X)'' be the set of all 
[[Compact space|compact]] [[Open set|open subsets]] of ''X''. Then ''X'' is said to be ''spectral'' if it satisfies all of the following conditions:
*''X'' is [[compact space|compact]] and [[Kolmogorov space|''T<sub>0</sub>'']].
* ''K<sup><math>\circ</math></sup>(X)'' is a basis of open subsets of ''X''.
* ''K<sup><math>\circ</math></sup>(X)'' is [[Closure (mathematics)|closed under]] finite intersections.
* ''X'' is [[Sober space|sober]], i.e. every nonempty [[Hyperconnected space|irreducible]] [[Closed set|closed subset]] of ''X'' has a (necessarily unique) [[generic point]].

==Equivalent descriptions==

Let ''X'' be a topological space. Each of the following properties are equivalent 
to the property of ''X'' being spectral:

#''X'' is [[homeomorphic]] to a [[projective limit]] of finite [[Kolmogorov space|''T<sub>0</sub>''-space]]s.
#''X'' is homeomorphic to the [[duality theory for distributive lattices|spectrum]] of a [[distributive lattice|bounded distributive lattice]] ''L''. In this case, ''L'' is isomorphic (as a bounded lattice) to the lattice ''K<sup><math>\circ</math></sup>(X)'' (this is called '''Stone representation of distributive lattices''').
#''X'' is homeomorphic to the [[Spectrum of a ring|spectrum of a commutative ring]].
#''X'' is the topological space determined by a [[Priestley space]].
#''X'' is a T<sub>0</sub> space whose [[Frames and locales|frame]] of open sets is coherent (and every coherent frame comes from a unique spectral space in this way).

==Properties==

Let ''X'' be a spectral space and let ''K<sup><math>\circ</math></sup>(X)'' be as before. Then:
*''K<sup><math>\circ</math></sup>(X)'' is a [[Lattice (order)|bounded sublattice]] of subsets of ''X''.
*Every closed [[Subspace topology|subspace]] of ''X'' is spectral.
*An arbitrary intersection of compact and open subsets of ''X'' (hence of elements from ''K<sup><math>\circ</math></sup>(X)'') is again spectral.
*''X'' is [[Kolmogorov space|T<sub>0</sub>]] by definition, but in general not [[T1 space|T<sub>1</sub>]].<ref>A.V. Arkhangel'skii, L.S. Pontryagin (Eds.) ''General Topology I'' (1990) Springer-Verlag {{isbn|3-540-18178-4}} ''(See example 21, section 2.6.)''</ref> In fact a spectral space is T<sub>1</sub> if and only if it is [[Hausdorff space|Hausdorff]] (or T<sub>2</sub>) if and only if it is a [[boolean space]] if and only if K<sup><math>\circ</math></sup>(X) is a [[boolean algebra]].
*''X'' can be seen as a [[Pairwise Stone space]].<ref>G. Bezhanishvili, N. Bezhanishvili, D. Gabelaia, A. Kurz, (2010). "Bitopological duality for distributive lattices and Heyting algebras." ''Mathematical Structures in Computer Science'', 20.</ref>

==Spectral maps==
A '''spectral map''' ''f: X → Y'' between spectral spaces ''X'' and ''Y'' is a continuous map such that the [[preimage]] of every open and compact subset of ''Y'' under ''f'' is  again compact.

The category of spectral spaces which has spectral maps as morphisms is [[Equivalence of categories|dually equivalent]] to the category of bounded distributive lattices (together with morphisms of such lattices).<ref>{{harv|Johnstone|1982}}</ref> In this anti-equivalence, a spectral space ''X'' corresponds to the lattice K<sup><math>\circ</math></sup>(X).

==References==

*[[Mel Hochster|M. Hochster]] (1969). Prime ideal structure in commutative rings. ''Trans. Amer. Math. Soc.'', 142 43—60

pages.title: Subsumption lattice
pages.text:
[[File:N5 terms.svg|thumb|'''Pic.1:''' Non-modular sublattice N<sub>5</sub> in subsumption lattice]]
A '''subsumption lattice''' is a mathematical structure used in theoretical background of [[automated theorem proving]] and other [[symbolic computation]] applications.

==Definition==
A [[Term (logic)|term]] ''t''<sub>1</sub> is said to ''subsume'' a term ''t''<sub>2</sub> if a [[Substitution (logic)|substitution]] ''σ'' exists such that ''σ'' applied to ''t''<sub>1</sub> yields ''t''<sub>2</sub>. In this case, ''t''<sub>1</sub> is also called ''more general than'' ''t''<sub>2</sub>, and ''t''<sub>2</sub> is called ''more specific than'' ''t''<sub>1</sub>, or ''an instance of'' ''t''<sub>1</sub>. 

The set of all (first-order) terms over a given [[Signature (logic)|signature]] can be made a [[Lattice (order)|lattice]] over the partial ordering relation "''... is more specific than ...''" as follows:
* consider two terms equal if they differ only in their variable naming,<ref>formally: factorize the set of all terms by the equivalence relation "''... is a renaming of ...''"; for example, the term ''f''(''x'',''y'') is a renaming of ''f''(''y'',''x''), but not of ''f''(''x'',''x'')</ref>
* add an artificial minimal element Ω (the ''overspecified term''), which is considered to be more specific than any other term. 
This lattice is called the subsumption lattice. Two terms are said to be unifiable if their meet differs from Ω.

==Properties==
[[File:Pairwise unifiable terms.gif|thumb|'''Pic.2:''' Part of the subsumption lattice showing that the terms ''f''(''a'',''x''), ''f''(''x'',''x''), and ''f''(''x'',''c'') are pairwise unifiable, but not simultaneously. (''f'' omitted for brevity.)]]
The [[Lattice_(order)#Lattices_as_posets|join and the meet operation]] in this lattice are called '''[[anti-unification (computer science)|anti-unification]]''' and '''[[Unification (computer science)|unification]]''', respectively. A variable ''x'' and the artificial element Ω are the [[Lattice_(order)#Lattices_as_posets|top and the bottom element]] of the lattice, respectively. Each [[ground term]], i.e.each  term without variables, is an [[Lattice_(order)#Important_lattice-theoretic_notions|atom]] of the lattice. The lattice has infinite descending [[Chain_(order_theory)#Chains|chains]], e.g. ''x'', ''g''(''x''), ''g''(''g''(''x'')), ''g''(''g''(''g''(''x''))), ..., but no infinite ascending ones.

If ''f'' and ''g'' is a binary and unary function symbol, respectively, and ''x'' and ''y'' denote variables, then the terms ''f''(''x'',''y''), ''f''(''g''(''x''),''y''), ''f''(''g''(''x''),''g''(''y'')), ''f''(''x'',''x''), and ''f''(''g''(''x''),''g''(''x'')) form the [[Modular lattice|minimal non-modular lattice N<sub>5</sub>]] (see pic.1); its appearance prevents the subsumption lattice from being [[Modular lattice|modular]] and hence also from being [[Distributive lattice|distributive]].

The set of terms unifiable with a given term need not be closed w.r.t. meet; pic.2 shows a counter-example.

Denoting by ''Gnd''(''t'') the set of all ground instances of a term ''t'', the following properties hold:<ref>{{cite journal|first1=John C.|last1=Reynolds|author-link1=John C. Reynolds|title=Transformational Systems and the Algebraic Structure of Atomic Formulas|journal=Machine Intelligence|editor1-first=B.|editor1-last=Meltzer|editor2-first=D.|editor2-last=Michie|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|volume=5|pages=135–151|year=1970|url=http://www.cs.cmu.edu/afs/cs/user/jcr/ftp/transysalg.pdf}}</ref>
* ''t'' equals the join of all members of ''Gnd''(''t''), modulo renaming,
* ''t''<sub>1</sub> is an instance of ''t''<sub>2</sub> if and only if ''Gnd''(''t<sub>1</sub>'') is a subset of ''Gnd''(''t<sub>2</sub>''),
* terms with the same set of ground instances are equal modulo renaming,
* if ''t'' is the meet of ''t''<sub>1</sub> and ''t''<sub>2</sub>, then ''Gnd''(''t'') is the intersection of ''Gnd''(''t<sub>1</sub>'') and ''Gnd''(''t<sub>2</sub>''),
* if ''t'' is the join of ''t''<sub>1</sub> and ''t''<sub>2</sub>, then ''Gnd''(''t'') contains the union of ''Gnd''(''t<sub>1</sub>'') and ''Gnd''(''t<sub>2</sub>'').

==Sublattice of linear terms==

{| style="float:right"
| [[File:generalizations_of_abc.gif|thumb|x150px|'''Pic.5:''' Distributive sublattice of linear terms]]
|}
{| style="float:right"
| [[File:M3 linear terms.svg|thumb|x150px|'''Pic.4:''' M<sub>3</sub> built from linear terms]]
|}
{| style="float:right"
| [[File:N5 linear terms.svg|thumb|x150px|'''Pic.3:''' N<sub>5</sub> built from linear terms]]
|}
The set of ''linear'' terms, that is of terms without multiple occurrences of a variable, is a sublattice of the subsumption lattice. This lattice, too, contains N<sub>5</sub> and the [[Distributive_lattice#Characteristic_properties|minimal non-distributive lattice M<sub>3</sub>]] as sublattices (see pic.3 and 4) and is hence not modular, let alone distributive.

The meet operation yields always the same result in the lattice of all terms and of linear terms.
The join operation in all terms lattice yields always an instance of the join in the linear terms lattice; for example, the (ground) terms ''f''(''a'',''a'') and ''f''(''b'',''b'') have the join ''f''(''x'',''x'') and ''f''(''x'',''y'') in all terms lattice and in the linear terms lattice, respectively.

Join and meet of two proper<ref>i.e. different from Ω</ref> linear terms, i.e. their anti-unification and unification, corresponds to intersection and union of their [[term (logic)#Operation with terms|path]] sets, respectively. Therefore, every sublattice of the lattice of linear terms that does not contain Ω is isomorphic to a set lattice, and hence distributive (see pic.5).

==Origin==
Apparently, the subsumption lattice was first investigated by [[Gordon D. Plotkin]], in 1970.<ref>{{cite book|last=Plotkin|first=Gordon D.|title=Lattice Theoretic Properties of Subsumption|date=Jun 1970|publisher=Univ., Dept. of Machine Intell. and Perception|location=Edinburgh}}</ref>

pages.title: Tamari lattice
pages.text:
[[Image:Tamari lattice.svg|thumb|250px|Tamari lattice of order 4]]
In mathematics, a '''Tamari lattice''', introduced by  {{harvs|txt|authorlink=Dov Tamari|first=Dov |last=Tamari|year=1962}}, is a [[partially ordered set]] in which the elements consist of different ways of grouping a sequence of objects into pairs using parentheses; for instance, for a sequence of four objects ''abcd'', the five possible groupings are ((''ab'')''c'')''d'', (''ab'')(''cd''), (''a''(''bc''))''d'', ''a''((''bc'')''d''), and ''a''(''b''(''cd'')). Each grouping describes a different order in which the objects may be combined by a [[binary operation]]; in the Tamari lattice, one grouping is ordered before another if the second grouping may be obtained from the first by only rightward applications of the [[associativity|associative law]] (''xy'')''z'' = ''x''(''yz''). For instance, applying this law with ''x'' = ''a'', ''y'' = ''bc'', and ''z'' = ''d'' gives the expansion (''a''(''bc''))''d'' = ''a''((''bc'')''d''), so in the ordering of the Tamari lattice (''a''(''bc''))''d'' ≤ ''a''((''bc'')''d'').

In this partial order, any two groupings ''g''<sub>1</sub> and ''g''<sub>2</sub> have a greatest common predecessor, the ''meet'' ''g''<sub>1</sub> ∧ ''g''<sub>2</sub>, and a least common successor, the ''join'' ''g''<sub>1</sub> ∨ ''g''<sub>2</sub>. Thus, the Tamari lattice has the structure of a [[Lattice (order)|lattice]]. The [[Hasse diagram]] of this lattice is [[Graph isomorphism|isomorphic]] to the [[skeleton (topology)|graph of vertices and edges]] of an [[associahedron]]. The number of elements in a Tamari lattice for a sequence of ''n'' + 1 objects is the ''n''th [[Catalan number]] C<sub>''n''</sub>.

The Tamari lattice can also be described in several other equivalent ways:
*It is the poset of sequences of ''n'' integers ''a''<sub>1</sub>, ..., ''a''<sub>''n''</sub>, ordered coordinatewise,  such that ''i'' ≤ ''a''<sub>''i''</sub> ≤ ''n''  and if ''i'' ≤ ''j'' ≤ ''a''<sub>''i''</sub> then ''a''<sub>''j''</sub> ≤ ''a''<sub>''i''</sub> {{harv|Huang|Tamari|1972}}.
*It is the poset of [[binary tree]]s with ''n'' leaves, ordered by [[tree rotation]] operations.
*It is the poset of [[tree (graph theory)|ordered forests]], in which one forest is earlier than another in the partial order if, for every ''j'', the ''j''th node in a [[preorder]] traversal of the first forest has at least as many descendants as the ''j''th node in a preorder traversal of the second forest {{harv|Knuth|2005}}.
*It is the poset of [[Triangulation (geometry)|triangulations]] of a convex ''n''-gon, ordered by flip operations that substitute one diagonal of the polygon for another.

==Notation==
The Tamari lattice of the [[Catalan number|C<sub>''n''</sub>]] groupings of ''n''+1 objects is called T<sub>''n''</sub>, but the corresponding [[associahedron]] is called K<sub>''n''+1</sub>.

In ''[[The Art of Computer Programming]]'' T<sub>4</sub> is called the ''Tamari lattice of order 4'' and its Hasse diagram K<sub>5</sub> the ''associahedron of order 4''.

pages.title: Tonnetz
pages.text:
[[File:Neo-Riemannian Tonnetz.svg|thumb|right|500px|A modern rendering of the Tonnetz. The A minor [[Triad (music)|triad]] is in strong blue, the C major triad in strong red. Interpreted as a torus the Tonnetz has 12 nodes (pitches) and 24 triangles (triads).]]

In [[musical tuning]] and [[harmony]], the '''Tonnetz''' ({{lang-de|tone-network}}) is a conceptual [[Lattice (music)|lattice]] [[diagram]] representing tonal space first described by [[Leonhard Euler]] in 1739.<ref>{{cite book
 | last = Euler
 | first = Leonhard
|authorlink=Leonhard Euler
 | year = 1739
 | language = Latin
 | title = '''Tentamen novae theoriae musicae ex certissismis harmoniae principiis dilucide expositae'''
 | pages = 147
 | publisher = Saint Petersburg Academy
}}
</ref> Various visual representations of the ''Tonnetz'' can be used to show [[Tonality|traditional harmonic relationships]] in European classical music.

==History through 1900==
[[Image:Eulers tonnetz.png|thumb|left|Euler's Tonnetz.]]

The ''Tonnetz'' originally appeared in Euler's 1739 ''Tentamen novae theoriae musicae ex certissismis harmoniae principiis dilucide expositae''. Euler's Tonnetz, pictured at left, shows the triadic relationships of the perfect fifth and the major third: at the top of the image is the note F, and to the left underneath is C (a perfect fifth above F), and to the right is A (a major third above F). The space was rediscovered in 1858 by Ernst Naumann, and was disseminated in an 1866 treatise of [[Arthur von Oettingen]]. Oettingen and the influential musicologist [[Hugo Riemann]] (not to be confused with the mathematician [[Bernhard Riemann]]) explored the capacity of the space to chart harmonic motion between chords and modulation between keys. Similar understandings of the ''Tonnetz'' appeared in the work of many late-19th century German music theorists.<ref name="cohnintro">{{cite journal
|last1=Cohn|first1=Richard
|title=Introduction to Neo-Riemannian Theory: A Survey and a Historical Perspective
|journal=Journal of Music Theory|year=1998|volume=42|issue=2 Autumn|pages=167–180|ref=harv|jstor=843871|doi=10.2307/843871
}}</ref>

Oettingen and Riemann both conceived of the relationships in the chart being defined through [[just intonation]], which uses pure intervals. One can extend out one of the horizontal rows of the Tonnetz indefinitely, to form a never-ending sequence of perfect fifths: F-C-G-D-A-E-B-F#-C#-G#-D#-A#-E#-B#-Fx-Cx-Gx- (etc.) Starting with F, after 12 perfect fifths, one reaches E#. Perfect fifths in just intonation are slightly larger than the compromised fifths used in [[equal temperament]] tuning systems more common in the present. This means that when one stacks 12 fifths starting from F, the E# we arrive at will not be seven octaves above the F we started with. Oettingen and Riemann's ''Tonnetz'' thus extended on infinitely in every direction without actually repeating any pitches.

The appeal of the ''Tonnetz'' to 19th-century German theorists was that it allows spatial representations of tonal distance and tonal relationships. For example, looking at the dark blue A minor triad in the graphic at the beginning of the article, its parallel major triad (A-C#-E) is the triangle right below, sharing the vertices A and E. The relative major of A minor, C major (C-E-G) is the upper-right adjacent triangle, sharing the C and the E vertices. The dominant triad of A minor, E major (E-G#-B) is diagonally across the E vertex, and shares no other vertices. One important point is that every shared vertex between a pair of triangles is a shared pitch between chords - the more shared vertices, the more shared pitches the chord will have. This provides a visualization of the principle of parsimonious voice-leading, in which motions between chords are considered smoother when fewer pitches change. This principle is especially important in analyzing the music of late-19th century composers like Wagner, who frequently avoided traditional tonal relationships. <ref name="cohnintro"></ref>

==Twentieth-century reinterpretation==
{{main|Neo-Riemannian theory}}
[[Image:PLR on tonnetz.png|thumb|right|Neo-Riemannian music theory's PLR operations applied to a minor chord Q.]]

Recent research by [[Neo-Riemannian theory|Neo-Riemannian]] music theorists [[David Lewin]], Brian Hyer, and others, have revived the ''Tonnetz'' to further explore properties of pitch structures. <ref name="cohnintro"></ref> Modern music theorists generally construct the ''Tonnetz'' using [[equal temperament]],<ref name="cohnintro"></ref> and using pitch-classes, which make no distinction between octave transpositions of a pitch. Under equal temperament, the never-ending series of ascending fifths mentioned earlier becomes a cycle. Neo-Riemannian theorists typically assume enharmonic equivalence (in other words, Ab = G#), and so the two-dimensional plane of the 19th-century ''Tonnetz'' cycles in on itself in two different directions, and is mathematically [[isomorphic]] to a [[torus]]. Theorists have studied the structure of this new cyclical version using mathematical [[group theory]]{{citation needed|reason=Which theorists?|date=March 2016}}.

Neo-Riemannian theorists have also used the ''Tonnetz'' to visualize non-tonal triadic relationships. For example, the diagonal going up and to the left from C in the diagram at the beginning of the article forms a division of the octave in three [[major third]]s: C-Ab-E-C (the E is actually an Fb, and the final C a Dbb). Richard Cohn argues that while a sequence of triads built on these three pitches (C major, Ab major, and E major) cannot be adequately described using traditional concepts of functional harmony, this cycle has smooth voice leading and other important group properties which can be easily observed on the ''Tonnetz''. <ref>{{cite journal|last=Cohn|first=Richard|title=Maximally Smooth Cycles, Hexatonic Systems, and the Analysis of Late-Romantic Triadic Progressions|journal=Music Analysis|date=March 1996|volume=15|issue=1|pages=9–40|doi=10.2307/854168|jstor=854168}}</ref>

==Similarities to other graphical systems==
The [[harmonic table note layout]] is a recently{{when|date=May 2012}} developed musical interface that uses a note layout topologically equivalent to the Tonnetz.

A ''Tonnetz'' of the [[syntonic temperament]] can be derived from a given [[isomorphic keyboard]] by connecting lines of successive [[perfect fifth]]s, lines of successive [[major third]]s, and lines of successive [[minor third]]s.<ref>{{cite journal
|last1=Milne|first1=A.|last2=Sethares|first2=W. A.|last3=Plamondon|first3=J.
|authorlink2=William Sethares
|title=Invariant fingerings across a tuning continuum
|journal=Computer Music Journal|year=2007|volume=31|issue=4 Winter|pages=15–32|ref=harv|doi=10.1162/comj.2007.31.4.15}}</ref> Like a ''Tonnetz'' itself, the isomorphic keyboard is tuning invariant.
The [[topology]] of the [[syntonic temperament]]'s Tonnetz is generally [[Cylinder (geometry)|cylindrical]].

[[Image:QWERTY with Tonnetz.jpg|thumb|right|Tonnetz aligned with the notes of an ''[[isomorphic keyboard]]''.]]
[[Image:Chord Lattice.jpg|thumb|right|Tonnetz showing enclosed chords. Capitalized chords ('Xx') are major; others ('xx') are minor.]]

The ''Tonnetz'' is the [[dual graph]] of [[Arnold Schoenberg|Schoenberg]]'s '''chart of the regions''',<ref>{{cite book
 | last = Schoenberg
 | first = Arnold
 |author2=Stein, L.
  | year = 1969
 | title = '''Structural Functions of Harmony'''
 | publisher = Norton
 | location = New York
 | isbn = 978-0-393-00478-6
}}
</ref> and of course ''vice versa''. Research into music cognition has demonstrated that the human brain uses a "chart of the regions" to process tonal relationships.<ref>{{cite journal
 | first = Petr
 | last = Janata
 |author2=Jeffrey L. Birk |author3=John D. Van Horn |author4=Marc Leman |author5=Barbara Tillmann |author6=Jamshed J. Bharucha
  |date=December 2002
 | title = '''The Cortical Topography of Tonal Structures Underlying Western Music'''
 | journal = Science
 | volume = 298
 | issue = 5601
 | pages = 2167–2170
 | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/298/5601/2167
 | doi = 10.1126/science.1076262
 | pmid = 12481131
 |bibcode=2002Sci...298.2167J}}
</ref>

pages.title: Union-closed sets conjecture
pages.text:
{{unsolved|mathematics|If any two sets in some finite family of sets have a union that also belongs to the family, must some element belong to at least half of the sets in the family?}} In [[combinatorial mathematics]], the '''union-closed sets conjecture''' is an elementary problem, posed by [[Péter Frankl]] in 1979 and still open. A [[family of sets]] is said to be ''union-closed'' if the union of any two sets from the family remains in the family. The conjecture states:
For every finite union-closed family of finite sets, other than the family containing only the [[empty set]], there exists an element that belongs to at least half of the sets in the family.
==Equivalent forms== If ''F'' is a union-closed family of sets, the family of [[complement set]]s to sets in ''F'' is closed under intersection, and an element that belongs to at least half of the sets of ''F'' belongs to at most half of the complement sets. Thus, an equivalent form of the conjecture (the form in which it was originally stated) is that, for any intersection-closed family of sets that contains more than one set, there exists an element that belongs to at most half of the sets in the family. Although stated above in terms of families of sets, Frankl's conjecture has also been formulated and studied as a question in [[lattice theory]]. A [[lattice (order)|lattice]] is a [[partially ordered set]] in which for two elements ''x'' and ''y'' there is a unique greatest element less than or equal to both of them (the ''meet'' of ''x'' and ''y'') and a unique least element greater than or equal to both of them (the ''join'' of ''x'' and ''y''). The family of all subsets of a set ''S'', ordered by set inclusion, forms a lattice in which the meet is represented by the set-theoretic intersection and the join is represented by the set-theoretic union; a lattice formed in this way is called a [[Boolean algebra (structure)|Boolean lattice]]. The lattice-theoretic version of Frankl's conjecture is that in any finite [[lattice (order)|lattice]] there exists an element ''x'' that is not the join of any two smaller elements, and such that the number of elements greater than or equal to ''x'' totals at most half the lattice, with equality only if the lattice is a Boolean lattice. As {{harvtxt|Abe|2000}} shows, this statement about lattices is equivalent to the Frankl conjecture for union-closed sets: each lattice can be translated into a union-closed set family, and each union-closed set family can be translated into a lattice, such that the truth of the Frankl conjecture for the translated object implies the truth of the conjecture for the original object. This lattice-theoretic version of the conjecture is known to be true for several natural subclasses of lattices{{harvtxt|Abe|2000}}; {{harvtxt|Poonen|1992}}; {{harvtxt|Reinhold|2000}} but remains open in the general case. Another equivalent formulation of the union-closed sets conjecture uses [[graph theory]]. In an [[undirected graph]], an [[Independent set (graph theory)|independent set]] is a set of vertices no two of which are adjacent to each other; an independent set is [[maximal independent set|maximal]] if it is not a subset of a larger independent set. In any graph, the "heavy" vertices that appear in more than half of the maximal independent sets must themselves form an independent set, so there always exists at least one non-heavy vertex, a vertex that appears in at most half of the maximal independent sets. The graph formulation of the union-closed sets conjecture states that every finite non-empty graph contains two adjacent non-heavy vertices. It is automatically true when the graph contains an odd cycle, because the independent set of all heavy vertices cannot cover all the edges of the cycle. Therefore, the more interesting case of the conjecture is for [[bipartite graph]]s, which have no odd cycles. Another equivalent formulation of the conjecture is that, in every bipartite graph, there exist two vertices, one on each side of the bipartition, such that each of these two vertices belongs to at most half of the graph's maximal independent sets. This conjecture is known to hold for [[chordal bipartite graph]]s, bipartite [[series-parallel graph]]s, and bipartite graphs of maximum [[degree (graph theory)|degree]] three.{{sfnp|Bruhn|Charbit|Schaudt|Telle|2015}} ==Families known to satisfy the conjecture== The conjecture has been proven for many special cases of union-closed set families. In particular, it is known to be true for * families of at most 46 sets.{{sfnp|Roberts|Simpson|2010}} * families of sets whose union has at most 11 elements.{{harvtxt|Bošnjak|Marković|2008}}, improving previous bounds by {{harvtxt|Morris|2006}}, {{harvtxt|Lo Faro|1994}} and others. * families of sets in which the smallest set has one or two elements.{{harvtxt|Sarvate|Renaud|1989}}, since rediscovered by several other authors. If a one-element or two-element set ''S'' exists, some element of ''S'' belongs to at least half the sets in the family, but the same property does not hold for three-element sets, due to counterexamples of Sarvate, Renaud, and [[Ronald Graham]]. * families of at least (\tfrac{1}{2}-\varepsilon)2^n subsets of an n-element set, for some constant \varepsilon>0.{{sfnp|Karpas|2017}} ==History== [[Péter Frankl]] stated the conjecture, in terms of intersection-closed set families, in 1979, and so the conjecture is usually credited to him and sometimes called the '''Frankl conjecture'''. The earliest publication of the union-closed version of the conjecture appears to be by {{harvtxt|Duffus|1985}}. == Notes == {{reflist}} == References == *{{cite journal | last = Abe | first = Tetsuya | title = Strong semimodular lattices and Frankl's conjecture | journal = Algebra Universalis | volume = 44 | year = 2000 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 379–382 | doi = 10.1007/s000120050195 | ref = harv}} *{{cite journal | last1 = Bošnjak | first1 = Ivica | last2 = Marković | first2 = Peter | title = The 11-element case of Frankl's conjecture | journal = [[Electronic Journal of Combinatorics]] | volume = 15 | issue = 1 | year = 2008 | pages = R88 | url = http://www.combinatorics.org/Volume_15/Abstracts/v15i1r88.html | ref = harv}} *{{cite journal | last1 = Bruhn | first1 = Henning | last2 = Charbit | first2 = Pierre | last3 = Schaudt | first3 = Oliver | last4 = Telle | first4 = Jan Arne | arxiv = 1212.4175 | doi = 10.1016/j.ejc.2014.08.030 | journal = [[European Journal of Combinatorics]] | mr = 3266293 | pages = 210–219 | title = The graph formulation of the union-closed sets conjecture | volume = 43 | year = 2015 | ref = harv}} *{{cite conference | authorlink = Dwight Duffus | last = Duffus | first = D. | title = Open problem session | conference = Graphs and Order | editor = [[Ivan Rival|Rival, I.]] | publisher = D. pages.title: Robert P. Dilworth
pages.text:
{{no footnotes|date=December 2017}}
'''Robert Palmer Dilworth''' (December 2, 1914 – October 29, 1993) was an American [[mathematician]]. His primary research area was [[lattice theory]]; his biography at the [[MacTutor History of Mathematics archive]] states "it would not be an exaggeration to say that he was one of the main factors in the subject moving from being merely a tool of other disciplines to an important subject in its own right". He is best known for [[Dilworth's theorem]] {{harv|Dilworth|1950}} relating [[chain (order theory)|chains]] and antichains in [[partial order]]s; he was also the first to study [[antimatroid]]s {{harv|Dilworth|1940}}.

Dilworth was born in 1914 in [[Hemet, California]], at that time a remote desert ranching town. He went to college at the [[California Institute of Technology]], receiving his baccalaureate in 1936 and continuing there for his graduate studies. Dilworth's graduate advisor was [[Morgan Ward]], a student of [[Eric Temple Bell]], who was also on the Caltech faculty at the time. On receiving his Ph.D. in 1939, Dilworth took an instructorship at [[Yale University]]. While at Yale, he met and married his wife, Miriam White, with whom he eventually had two sons. He returned to Caltech as a faculty member in 1943, and spent the remainder of his academic career there. 
Dilworth advised 17 Ph.D. students and {{As of|2010|lc=on}} has 373 academic descendants listed at the [[Mathematics Genealogy Project]], many through his student [[Juris Hartmanis]], a noted [[Computational complexity theory|complexity theorist]]. Other notable mathematicians advised by Dilworth include [[Curtis Greene]] and [[Alfred W. Hales]].

[[Homology (mathematics)|Homology]] of [[lattice (order)|lattices]] and [[matroid]]s | prizes = [[Putnam Fellow]] (1960) | religion = | footnotes = }} '''Jon Hal Folkman''' (December 8, 1938 – January 23, 1969)Birth and death dates from {{citation|first1=R. L.|last1=Graham|author1-link=R. L. Graham|first2=B. L.|last2=Rothschild|author2-link=Bruce Lee Rothschild|title=Ramsey's theorem for ''n''-parameter sets|journal=Transactions of the American Mathematical Society|volume=159|pages=257–292|url=http://www.math.ucsd.edu/~sbutler/ron/71_04_n_ramsey.pdf|doi=10.2307/1996010|jstor=1996010|year=1971}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, and from {{citation|first=Joel|last=Spencer|authorlink=Joel Spencer|title=Optimal ranking of tournaments|year=1971|issue=2|journal=Networks|volume=1|pages=135–138|doi=10.1002/net.3230010204}}, both of which were dedicated to the memory of Folkman. was an American mathematician, a student of [[John Milnor]], and a researcher at the [[RAND Corporation]]. ==Schooling== Folkman was a [[William Lowell Putnam Mathematical Competition|Putnam Fellow]] in 1960.[http://www.maa.org/awards/putnam.html Putnam competition results], Mathematical Association of America, retrieved 2010-10-17. He received his Ph.D. in 1964 from [[Princeton University]], under the supervision of Milnor, with a thesis entitled ''Equivariant Maps of Spheres into the Classical Groups''.{{mathgenealogy|name=John Hal Folkman|id=22443}}. ==Research== [[File:Folkman graph alt.svg|thumb|Jon Folkman found the [[semi-symmetric graph]] with the fewest possible vertices, the [[Folkman graph]].]] Jon Folkman contributed important theorems in many areas of [[combinatorics]]. In [[geometric combinatorics]], Folkman is known for his pioneering and posthumously-published studies of [[oriented matroid]]s; in particular, the Folkman–Lawrence topological representation theorem{{citation | last1 = Folkman | first1 = J. | last2 = Lawrence | first2 = J. | doi = 10.1016/0095-8956(78)90039-4 | issue = 2 | journal = Journal of Combinatorial Theory, Series B | pages = 199–236 | title = Oriented matroids | volume = 25 | year = 1978}}. is "one of the cornerstones of the theory of oriented matroids".Page 17: {{cite book|last=Björner|first=Anders|last2=Las Vergnas|first2=Michel | author2-link=Michel Las Vergnas | last3=Sturmfels|first3=Bernd|authorlink3=bernd Sturmfels|last4=White|first4=Neil|last5=Ziegler|first5=Günter|authorlink5=Günter M. Ziegler|title=Oriented Matroids|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1999|isbn=978-0-521-77750-6}} The Folkman-Lawrence representation theorem is called the "Lawrence representation theorem" by [[Günter M. Ziegler]] in remark 7.23 on page 211: {{cite book|authorlink=Günter M. Ziegler|last=Ziegler|first=Günter M.|title=Lectures on Polytopes|series=Graduate texts in mathematics|volume=152|publisher=Springer-Verlag|year=1995|location=New York|isbn=0-387-94365-X |id=(paper), }} In [[lattice (order)|lattice]] theory, Folkman solved an [[open problem]] on the foundations of [[enumerative combinatorics|combinatorics]] by proving a [[conjecture]] of [[Gian-Carlo Rota|Gian–Carlo Rota]]; in proving Rota's conjecture, Folkman characterized the structure of the [[homology (mathematics)|homology groups]] of [[matroid|"geometric lattices"]] in terms of the [[free group|free]] [[Abelian group]]s of [[rank of a group|finite rank]]. * {{cite book|last=Kung|first=Joseph P. S. (ed.)|chapter=III Enumeration in geometric lattices, 2. Homology|title=A Source book in matroid theory|publisher=Birkhäuser Boston, Inc.|location=Boston, MA|year=1986|isbn=0-8176-3173-9|pages=201–202|mr=890330}} ** {{cite news|last=Folkman|first=Jon |title=The homology groups of a lattice|journal=Journal of Mathematics and Mechanics|volume=15|year=1966|pages=631–636|mr=188116}} ** {{cite book|last1=Folkman|first1=Jon|chapter=The homology groups of a lattice|pages=243–248|last2=Kung|first2=Joseph P. S. (ed.)|title=A Source book in matroid theory|publisher=Birkhäuser Boston, Inc.|location=Boston, MA|year=1986|isbn=0-8176-3173-9|mr=188116}} **{{cite news|last=Rota|first=Gian-Carlo|authorlink=Gian-Carlo Rota|title=On the foundations of combinatorial theory, I: Theory of Möbius functions|journal=Zeitschrift für Wahrscheinlichkeitstheorie und Verwandte Gebiete (Probability theory and related fields)|volume=2|year=1964|pages=340–368|doi=10.1007/BF00531932|mr=174487 }} **{{cite book|last1=Rota|first1=Gian-Carlo|authorlink1=Gian-Carlo Rota|chapter=On the foundations of combinatorial theory, I: Theory of Möbius functions|pages=213–242|doi=10.1007/BF00531932|last2=Kung |first2=Joseph P. S. (ed.)|title=A Source book in matroid theory|publisher=Birkhäuser Boston, Inc.|location=Boston, MA|year=1986|isbn=0-8176-3173-9|mr=174487}} In [[graph theory]], he was the first to study [[semi-symmetric graph]]s, and he discovered the semi-symmetric graph with the fewest possible vertices, now known as the [[Folkman graph]].{{citation | first = J. | last = Folkman | title = Regular line-symmetric graphs | journal = Journal of Combinatorial Theory | volume =3 | year = 1967 | pages = 215–232 | doi = 10.1016/S0021-9800(67)80069-3}}. He proved the existence, for every positive ''h'', of a finite ''K''''h'' + 1-free graph which has a monocolored ''Kh'' in every 2-coloring of the edges, settling a problem previously posed by [[Paul Erdős]] and [[András Hajnal]].{{citation|first=J.|last=Folkman|title= Graphs with monochromatic complete subgraphs in every edge coloring|journal=SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics|volume=18|year=1970|pages=19–24|mr=0268080|doi=10.1137/0118004}}. He further proved that if ''G'' is a finite graph such that every set ''S'' of vertices contains an independent set of size (|''S''| − ''k'')/2 then the chromatic number of ''G'' is at most ''k'' + 2.J. Folkman: An upper bound on the chromatic number of a graph, in: Combinatorial theory and its application, II (Proc. Colloq., Balatonfüred, 1969), North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1970, 437–457. In [[convex geometry]], Folkman worked with his [[RAND Corporation|RAND]] colleague [[Lloyd Shapley]] to prove the [[Shapley–Folkman lemma|Shapley–Folkman lemma and theorem]]: Their results suggest that [[Minkowski addition|sums of sets]] are approximately convex; in [[mathematical economics]] their results are used to explain why [[general equilibrium theory|economies with many agents]] have approximate [[economic equilibrium|equilibria]], despite individual nonconvexities.{{citation | last = Starr | first = Ross M. | authorlink = Ross Starr | issue = 1 | journal = Econometrica | pages = 25–38 | title = Quasi-equilibria in markets with non-convex preferences (Appendix 2: The Shapley–Folkman theorem, pp. 35–37) | volume = 37 | year = 1969 | jstor=1909201 | doi=10.2307/1909201| citeseerx = 10.1.1.297.8498}}. In [[additive combinatorics]], [[Folkman's theorem]] states that for each assignment of finitely many colors to the positive integers, there exist arbitrarily large sets of integers all of whose nonempty sums have the same color; the name was chosen as a memorial to Folkman by his friends.Page 81 in {{Citation |authorlink=Ronald Graham |first=R. |last=Graham |first2=B. |last2=Rothschild |authorlink3=Joel Spencer |first3=J. H. |last3=Spencer |title=Ramsey Theory |publisher=John Wiley and Sons |location=New York |year=1990 |isbn=0-471-50046-1 |edition=2nd }}. In [[Ramsey theory]], the Rado–Folkman–Sanders theorem describes "[[partition regular]]" sets. ===The Folkman Number F(p, q; r)=== For r > max{p, q}, let F(p, q; r) denote the minimum number of vertices in a graph G that has the following properties: # G contains no complete subgraph on r vertices, # in any green-red coloring of the edges of G there is either a green Kp or a red Kq subgraph. Some results are *F(3, 3; 5) < 18 (Martin Erickson) *F(2, 3; 4) < 1000 ([[Vojtěch Rödl]], Andrzej Dudek) ==Brain cancer and despair== [[File:Erdos head budapest fall 1992.jpg|thumb|[[Paul Erdős]] visited Jon Folkman after Folkman awoke from surgery for brain cancer. To restore Folkman's confidence, Erdős immediately challenged him to solve [[mathematical problem]]s.]] In the late 1960s, Folkman suffered from [[brain cancer]]; while hospitalized, Folkman was visited repeatedly by [[Ronald Graham]] and [[Paul Erdős]]. After his brain surgery, Folkman was despairing that he had lost his mathematical skills. As soon as Folkman received Graham and Erdős at the hospital, Erdős challenged Folkman with mathematical problems, helping to rebuild his [[Self-confidence|confidence]]. Folkman later purchased a gun and killed himself. Folkman's supervisor at RAND, [[Delbert Ray Fulkerson]], blamed himself for failing to notice suicidal behaviors in Folkman. Years later Fulkerson also killed himself.{{citation|title=[[The man who loved only numbers|The man who loved only numbers: the story of Paul Erdős and the search for mathematical truth]]| first=Paul|last=Hoffman|authorlink=Paul Hoffman (science writer)|publisher=Hyperion|year=1998 |isbn=978-0-7868-6362-4|pages=109–110}}. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Folkman, John Hal}} [[Category:Additive combinatorialists]] [[Category:RAND Corporation people]] [[Category:Putnam Fellows]] [[Category:20th-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:Mathematicians who committed suicide]] [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:1969 deaths]] [[Category:Lattice theorists]] [[Category:Mathematicians from Utah]] [[Category:People from Ogden, Utah]]

pages.title: Alfred Horn
pages.text:
'''Alfred Horn''' (February 17, 1918 – April 16, 2001) was an [[United States|American]] [[mathematician]] notable for his work in [[lattice theory]] and [[universal algebra]]. His 1951 paper "On sentences which are true of direct unions of algebras" described [[Horn clause]]s and [[Horn sentence]]s, which later would form the foundation of [[logic programming]].[[File:Prof Alfred Horn of East Palisades CA 1973 passport photo.jpg|thumb|<center>Alfred Horn about 1973</center>]]

==Biography==
Horn was born on [[Lower East Side, Manhattan]]. His parents were both [[deaf]], and his father died when Horn was three years old. At this point, the children moved in with their grandparents on the mother's side. They would later move to [[Brooklyn]] where Horn spent most of his childhood, raised by his extended family.

Horn attended the [[City College of New York]], and later, [[New York University]] where he earned a [[Master's degree]] in [[mathematics]]. He went on to earn his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] at [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 1946. A year later, he started work at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]], where he stayed until his retirement in 1988.

He died in 2001 in [[Pacific Palisades, Los Angeles]] after eight years of battling [[prostate cancer]].

'''John Rolfe Isbell''' (October 27, 1930 – August 6, 2005)Birth date from [http://genforum.genealogy.com/isbell/messages/2234.html an excerpt] of "The Harloe-Kelso Genealogy" by C. B. Harloe (1943), accessed 2011-03-23; death date from death announcement in the [[Buffalo News]], August 28, 2005, [http://files.usgwarchives.net/ny/erie/obits/bn-dn/2005/aug/bn-dn28aug2005.txt reproduced by usgwarchives.net], accessed 2011-03-23. {{harvtxt|Magill|1996}} also states his birth date as 1930, but {{harvtxt|Henriksen|2006}} states it as 1931. was an American mathematician, for many years a professor of mathematics at the [[University at Buffalo|University at Buffalo (SUNY)]]. ==Biography== Isbell was born in [[Portland, Oregon]], the son of an army officer from Isbell, a town in [[Franklin County, Alabama]].Harloe (1943).{{citation|first=K. D., Jr.|last=Magill|title=An interview with John Isbell|journal=Topology Communications|volume=1|issue=2|year=1996|url=http://at.yorku.ca/t/o/p/c/06.htm}}.{{citation|first=Melvin|last=Henriksen|title=John Isbell 1931–2005|journal=Topology Communications|volume=11|issue=1|year=2006|url=http://at.yorku.ca/t/o/p/d/64.htm}}. He attended several undergraduate institutions, including the [[University of Chicago]], where professor [[Saunders Mac Lane]] was a source of inspiration. He began his graduate studies in mathematics at Chicago, briefly studied at [[Oklahoma State University–Stillwater|Oklahoma A&M University]] and the [[University of Kansas]],The [[University of Kansas]] had professors Ainsley Diamond and [[Nachman Aronszajn]], who had previously been professors at Oklahoma A&M. The two moved to Kansas after Oklahoma A&M had instituted a requirement that instructors sign a strict [[loyalty oath]]. Ainsley Diamond, as a [[quaker]], had refused to sign the loyalty oath. and eventually completed a Ph.D. in [[game theory]] at [[Princeton University]] in 1954 under the supervision of [[Albert W. Tucker]].{{mathgenealogy|name=John Rolfe Isbell|id=18496}}. After graduation, Isbell was drafted into the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]], and stationed at the [[Aberdeen Proving Ground]]. In the late 1950s he worked at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in [[Princeton, New Jersey]], from which he then moved to the [[University of Washington]] and [[Case Western Reserve University]]. He joined the [[University at Buffalo]] in 1969, and remained there until his retirement in 2002.[http://at.yorku.ca/i/a/a/l/11.htm Announcement of Isbell's death] in ''Topology News'', October 2005. ==Research== Isbell published over 140 papers under his own name, and several others under [[pseudonym]]s. Isbell published the first paper by [[John Rainwater]], a fictitious mathematician who had been invented by graduate students at the University of Washington in 1952. After Isbell's paper, other mathematicians have published papers using the name "Rainwater" and have acknowledged "Rainwater's assistance" in articles.The seminar on [[functional analysis]] at the University of Washington has been called the "Rainwater seminar".

{{cite journal|title=Biography of John Rainwater|first=Robert R.|last=Phelps|authorlink=Robert R. Phelps|journal=Topological Commentary|volume=7|number=2|year=2002|editor=Melvin Henriksen|url=http://at.yorku.ca/t/o/p/d/45.htm|ref=harv}}{{anchor|Stanley}}{{anchor|Enos}} Isbell published other articles using two additional pseudonyms, '''M. G. Stanley''' and '''H. C. Enos''', publishing two under each. Many of his works involved [[topology]] and [[category theory]]: *He was "the leading contributor to the theory of [[uniform space]]s". *Isbell duality is a form of [[duality (mathematics)|duality]] arising when a mathematical object can be interpreted as a member of two different [[category (mathematics)|categories]]; a standard example is the [[Stone duality]] between [[sober space]]s and [[complete Heyting algebra]]s with sufficiently many points.{{citation|title=Isbell duality|first1=Michael|last1=Barr|first2=John F.|last2=Kennison|first3=R.|last3=Raphael|journal=Theory and Applications of Categories|volume=20|issue=15|pages=504–542|year=2008|url=http://www.tac.mta.ca/tac/volumes/20/15/20-15.pdf}}. *Isbell was the first to study the [[category of metric spaces]] defined by [[metric space]]s and the [[metric map]]s between them, and did early work on [[injective metric space]]s and the [[tight span]] construction.{{citation | author = Isbell, J. R. | title = Six theorems about injective metric spaces | journal = [[Commentarii Mathematici Helvetici]] | volume = 39 | issue = 1 | year = 1964 | pages = 65–76 | url = http://www.digizeitschriften.de/resolveppn/GDZPPN002058340 | doi = 10.1007/BF02566944}}. In [[abstract algebra]], Isbell found a rigorous formulation for the [[Pierce–Birkhoff conjecture]] on piecewise-polynomial functions.{{citation|first=James J. |last=Madden |url=http://atlas-conferences.com/c/a/c/v/66.htm |contribution=The Pierce–Birkhoff Conjecture |title=International Conference and Workshop on Valuation Theory |year=1999 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608074427/http://atlas-conferences.com/c/a/c/v/66.htm |archivedate=2011-06-08 |df= }}. He also made important contributions to the theory of [[median algebra]]s.{{citation | last=Isbell | first=John R. | title=Median algebra | journal=[[Transactions of the American Mathematical Society]] | volume=260 | issue=2 | date=August 1980 | pages=319–362 | doi=10.2307/1998007 | jstor=1998007}}. In [[geometric graph theory]], Isbell was the first to prove the bound χ ≤ 7 on the [[Hadwiger–Nelson problem]], the question of how many colors are needed to [[graph coloring|color]] the points of the plane in such a way that no two points at unit distance from each other have the same color.{{citation | last = Soifer | first = Alexander | authorlink = Alexander Soifer | isbn = 978-0-387-74640-1 | location = New York | publisher = Springer | title = The Mathematical Coloring Book: Mathematics of Coloring and the Colorful Life of its Creators | year = 2008|page=29}}. ==See also== *[[Isbell conjugacy]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External resources== ===Mathematical Reviews=== * {{Cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/mathscinet/search/author.html?mrauthid=91685|title='''John R. Isbell'''|author=[[Mathematical Reviews]]|accessdate=2011-04-02}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *Pseudonyms used by Isbell (and other mathematicians): ** {{Cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/mathscinet/search/author.html?mrauthid=248269|title=John Rainwater|author=[[Mathematical Reviews]]|accessdate=2011-04-02}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} **{{Cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/mathscinet/search/author.html?mrauthid=212079|title=M. {{more footnotes|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Øystein Ore | image = ØysteinOre.jpg | image_size = | caption = Øystein Ore | birth_date = {{Birth date|1899|10|7|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Oslo]], [[Norway]] | residence = [[Norway]]
[[United States|U.S.]] | nationality = [[Norway|Norwegian]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1968|8|13|1899|10|7|df=y}} | death_place = [[Oslo]], [[Norway]] | field = [[Mathematician]] | work_institution = [[Oslo University]]
